revised_title: The Role of Modified Plant Pigments in Lepidopterous Larvae Coloration
tldr: The author conducted experiments to test the theory that some colors of certain lepidopterous larvae are made up of modified chlorophyll and etiolin derived from their food plant. The results showed that larvae fed on green and yellow etiolated leaves developed green or brown ground colors, proving that both chlorophyll and etiolin can form the basis of larval coloration. This study provides evidence for the role of modified plant pigments in the coloration of lepidopterous larvae.
